title: 106_s382
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" have national significance as the best preserved examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication and preparedness of Air Force missileers stationed in remote locations in the upper Great Plains. The Minuteman II missile defense system facilities in remote Great Plains locations during the Cold War are of national significance. The Act aims to preserve and interpret these structures to showcase the history and importance of the Cold War, arms race, and ICBM development. The National Park System lacks a unit dedicated to commemorating the Cold War. The Act aims to interpret the historical role of the Minuteman II missile defense system in the context of the Cold War and America's strategic commitment to world peace. It also aims to complement interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established under SEC. 3. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established in South Dakota as a unit of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota includes the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Control Facilities for Minuteman II ICBMs. The map of the site is available for public inspection, and the Secretary of the Interior can make minor boundary adjustments. The Secretary is authorized to make minor boundary adjustments to the historic site and administer it in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary may consult with other agencies, enter into cooperative agreements, and acquire land for the historic site as authorized by relevant laws. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site boundaries through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, except for contaminated land. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site boundaries through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, except for contaminated land. The Secretary may acquire land in South Dakota only by donation or exchange. A General Management Plan must be developed within 3 years after funds are allocated. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the historic site within 3 years of funds allocation. The plan should evaluate suitable locations for a visitor facility and administrative site within designated areas on the map. The Secretary will modify the historic site boundary to include a selected site for a visitor facility and administrative functions. Coordination with Badlands National Park is required for administrative and management functions. Authorization of appropriations for the selected site for a visitor facility and administrative functions. Coordination with Badlands National Park is required. Authorization of appropriations for the establishment and maintenance of a historic site, with funds transferred from the Air Force for this purpose. The Legacy Resource Management Program's funding remains unaffected by this Act. The Act authorizes funds for establishing and maintaining a historic site, with no impact on the Legacy Resource Management Program's funding.
